statement.tex: \text{Find all the points of discontinuity}\\ \text{of f defined as }f(x) = \vert x\vert - \vert x+1\vert.
\\ \text{Which of the following shows the}\\ \text{correct definitions for }\vert x\vert\text{ and }\vert x+1\vert ?

reason.tex: \text{The tricky function is }\vert x+1\vert. \\ \text{And the trick is to see }\vert x + 1\vert \text{ as }\vert y \vert\\ \text{where } y = x + 1.

\text{Be careful.} \vert x\vert \text{is defined differently}\\ \text{around }x=0.\text{ But }\vert x+1\vert\text{ is defined }\\ \text{differently around }x=-1.f(x) = \vertx\vert-\vert x+1\vert \text{must}\\ \text{therefore take both }x=0\text{ and }x=-1\text{ into account.}
\text{From the previous step, we know f(x) is}\\ \text{continuous for }x\neq 0\text{ and }x\neq -1.\text{Now, we}\\ \text{have shown f(x) is continuous for }x=-1, 0.
